title: Emmerdale dedicates episode to Zoe Tate star Leah Bracknell after death
text:
Emmerdale dedicated tonight’s episode to the memory of Leah Bracknell after news broke that she’d passed away from a three-year battle with lung cancer aged 55.

The actress was best known for her role in the ITV soap, played the complicated Zoe Tate from 1989-2005.

She left behind a legacy on the show that included groundbreaking storylines for mental health, as Zoe battle schizophrenia, and also the LGBT community as she played the first gay character in soapland.

Her reputation preceded her and left a mark on her soap co-stars, including Dominic Brunt and Lisa Riley, who led tributes to the star as news of her death broke.

On tonight’s episode, which featured Robert Sugden (Ryan Hawley) handing himself into the police, the credits ended with a touching tribute.

Leah’s manager confirmed her passing today in a statement that read: ‘It is with the deepest sadness that Leah Bracknell’s family confirm that Leah passed away in September, three years after her diagnosis with stage four lung cancer.’

‘They would like to thank all the public for their support and generosity which contributed to the extension and quality of her life over the past three years. Leah continued to embrace life and faced her illness with positivity. Many aspects of her journey can be found on her blog.’

‘Leah had an energy and enthusiasm for life, a kind heart and much love to give to those around her,’ they continued.

‘Her family have asked for privacy at this very sad time.’

Leah documented her cancer journey on blog Something Beginning With C, and talked about the importance of ‘keeping your head above water’ and ’embracing life’.

Born Alison Rosalind Bracknell in 1964, Leah leaves behind two children and her partner Jez Hughes.

Non smoker Leah also penned a poem about her condition, which she posted on Facebook. It read: ‘I got me a butterfly net to catch me all the love and beauty and wishes and dreams and black cat kinda luck.

‘And fire in my belly, honey in my heart kind of memories that melt my sweet heart and take away the pain.

‘I spy me a sky full of blessings coming my way. Net at the ready, I raise my head for a kiss. And here they come.’
